variant.question: The PDG is made up of

options.text: 2.5% gradient of obstacle identification plus 0.8% increasing obstacle clearance.
2.5% gradient of obstacle identification.
2.5% gradient of obstacle identification minus 0.8% increasing obstacle clearance.
0.8% increasing obstacle clearance.

variant.question: Relative to the ground a headwind ___ the effective climb angle and a tailwind ___ the effective climb angle.

options.text: increases; decreases
decreases; decreases
increases; increases
decreases; increases

variant.question: An aeroplane receives a late descent clearance from ATC due to opposite traffic with all factors being equal and constant.Choose the correct statement. The pilot may:

options.text: Increase the airspeed and therefore increasing the descent angle to regain the planned profile, reducing energy state of the aeroplane due to extra drag.
Slow down and use speed brakes to increase the drag and increase the descent angle since the speed brakes are more effective at lower airspeed.
Increase the airspeed and use flaps to regain the vertical profile, however, the aeroplane will have a higher energy state when back on the planned profile.
Use speed brakes and maintain planned descent speed, however, the aeroplane will have a higher energy state when back on the planned profile.

variant.question: You are the pilot of a transport category aeroplane and have just started a precision approach. You can recognise that you are too high and too fast on the descent path. You are flying in a (clean) aircraft configuration, which means that the landing gear is up and the flaps are retracted. What should you do?

options.text: Decrease airspeed to below VLO and extend the landing gear, followed by flaps to increase the drag and get back on the descent path and speed profile.
Decrease your airspeed and rate of descent to get back on your descent path. When back on the descent path, plan for a flaps-up approach with a higher airspeed.
Decrease your airspeed and rate of descent to get back on your descent path. When back on the descent path, reduce your airspeed and start extending flaps and landing gear on schedule.
Increase your airspeed, which will result in an increase in your rate of descent, allowing you to get back on the descent path.

variant.question: You are the pilot of a transport category aeroplane and have just started a precision approach. You can recognise that you are too high and too fast on the descent path. You are flying in a (clean) aircraft configuration, which means that the landing gear is up and the flaps are retracted. What should you do?

options.text: Decrease airspeed to below V~LO~ and extend the landing gear, followed by flaps , to increase drag and get back on the descent path and speed profile.
Decrease your airspeed and rate of descent to get back on your descent path. When back on the descent path, reduce your airspeed and start extending flaps and landing gear on schedule.
Decrease your airspeed and rate of descent to get back on your descent path. When back on the descent path, plan for a flaps-up approach with a higher airspeed.
Increase your airspeed, which will result in an increase in your rate of descent, allowing you to get back on the descent path.

variant.question: During a Constant Descent Arrival (CDA) a higher than forecast headwind is experienced putting the aircraft below the profile. What action is to be taken by the captain?

options.text: Reduce rate of descent to regain profile
Select speedbrakes
Contact ATC to inform them of your deviation and request new instructions
Reduce thrust

variant.question: An aircraft is on cruise when the pilot analyzes fuel consumption. The pilot finds out the aircraft is consuming more fuel than planned. At that moment, ATC instructs the pilot to descend at high speed. Which is the best speed to proceed?

options.text: LRC
Minimum power required
Minimum drag to achieve maximum range
MMO

variant.question: What is the purpose of a Continuous Descent Arrival (CDA)?

options.text: To stay higher for longer and operate at a lower engine thrust.
To allow more aircraft taxi at once on the airfield.
To descend earlier, fly faster, and thereby save time.
To descend earlier and operate at lower engine thrust.
